title: Using online networks to analyse the value of electronic music
segmentation: I'm presenting this project on behalf of my myself and my collaborators Daniel, Arlington and Byron do Echo at the Open University.
One thing I found out being in Slovenia, I found out that our project acronym VEMS is the Slovenian word for I know.
Yeah, which is wonderful serendipity.
So what we're looking at in this project, valuing electronic music?
How do you measure or assess or capture cultural value?
We touched on this a little in the panel discussion yesterday.
This idea of understanding, subjectivity, understanding of aesthetics.
Can we do this with the computer?
This is my attempt to say, perhaps, so we're focusing specifically on electronic music as a short term project.
So bring the boundaries in.
And when we started work, our questions were who were the main players in electronic music?
Terrible pun, no.
Laughs at all, like I'll drop that.
And also on more local level who values which musicians value other musicians and how do they actually show this?
How do they show their appreciation?
So what we?
Doing it's very tangled mixture of qualitative and quantitative work, so I'm much more on the quantitative end and we go to Byron.
Do Accusa music ologist on the project and ethnomusicologists.
We are using interviews with electronic musicians based in London.
Talk to some of you later and also we're using the website SoundCloud, which is a social network for musicians heavily populated by electronic musicians.
It seems to be in one guys or another.

The dominant type of music you find on SoundCloud, and it's a social network for musicians to interact, so we're using the two forms of research and various things alongside to combine together and explore this question of how value is shown for music.
Electronic music groups.
So I'm going to focus on the SoundCloud data analysis today.
So.
How do users actually interact on SoundCloud?
How do they use the social network so they can follow other users?
They can like somebody's track and they can comment on somebody's track.
There are other ways that they can interact as well.
They can create playlists of tracks and they can join groups of users, but in practice we found these two options aren't so.
Widely used, so I believe we have Kirsten Weiner in the room.
Yes, and also another one of our subjects bones.
So this is an example of the types of interaction, so you are following only two people.
But you have 348 followers congratulations, and so this is the kind of interactions that we're looking at, and this is the kind of data that we can pull from SoundCloud.
They've got a very good API.
I'm.
So this is the part of the talk where I stick to the paper and then because this is a late breaking paper, I will then go beyond what I've actually put in the paper.
We have some more findings.
So we concentrated originally on big data methods.
Who are the most top ranked users who have got the most followers who are ranked the highest in terms of indegree analysis using Pagerank algorithms?
So we have this list of our top 10 users in a particular sample that we took.
And we have our little diagrams of the networks of how people follow each other and the networks we've tried to prune them a little bit to make them more readable.
So the diagram furthest on the left.
Is the network of all connections and then we remove people who.
Don't follow anyone else in SoundCloud so people who aren't interacting in that way and then we remove people who don't have any followers and slowly we're getting a bit more readable diagrams, but.
The.
Problem all the way through was that this isn't useful for us.
We could have written the top 10, probably give or take.
We know who the bigger players are that really keep people are and the diagrams.
This is a sample of 500 users.
SoundCloud has millions.
Is not telling us very much.
And there's also.
Big mismatch with what we were finding out in the interviews.
This goes back to Simon's comment yesterday that when we go off and do this computational creativity work, we're thinking about it.
From our perspective, our own small, limited experience is actually once you go out there and talk to the people who are doing this stuff.
Talking to the musicians and finding out from a range of people what's important to them.
That's when the useful stuff comes in, so this has changed our direction.
So rather than concentrating on who are the big players who are the key musicians?
We found this so much more interest in the smaller groups, the subnetworks within the bigger network, and the word relationship has come up in.
I think almost every single interview we've done, I've just primed you for the interview idea.
Forget it said that.
So this idea that people are much more interested in building up relationships within smaller networks so.

We found I won't go into this, but we've found that there are very definite clusters of genres, so people are particularly interested in the more urban genres, and they built their own networks around that cluster or in things that are more house music, EDM, dance, music, or other types entirely.
So genre has a big influence on how you interact with people who are not necessarily that.
Bothered about what happens with people outside of your own interest of networks?
And there's also a geographical influence that we found, so some of our subjects that we've looked at.
They have very clear links with people in particular areas, and it's because they talk to them in the real world, in the offline world, and that comes through in what's happening in SoundCloud.
And as we've spoken to other people, what they do in SoundCloud has influence on what happens when they're promoting their music.
Back in the offline world.
I put in this picture here just to illustrate this a little bit more.
This is a venue that I was at last night with a couple of people.
It's called AKC Metelkova, a Cultural Center.
It used to be a military barracks in prison until the 90s and then since then the structures have been retained, but it's been turned into this graffiti strewn set of venues.
Very alternative very underground.
So the people going to gigs here don't care about who the top 10 people on SoundCloud though.
They have influence.
They're showing their interest and the venue is giving influence to people on a much more local level and much more underground level.
So one thing we've
We started being interested in recently a comments, so people build up relationships by commenting on each other's tracks.
So in this diagram you have the little floaty avatars.
The circles represent tracks, and if they are linked together then they are tracked by the same user.
The green flash means that they are creating a track.
The Orange flash means that they're commenting on each other's tracks, and you see this hive of activity that's going on.
This is where people are building up influence with each other interacting, and this is where there's value being shown in these comments.
These conversations.
So.
I have no minutes left, so I'll stop there, so.
What I want to conclude is that we are finding for social network analysis to understand cultural value.
It's not the bigger picture, it's the smaller little pictures, so we're looking for how people build up relationships.
There's the project website where we're announcing various results, and I've got some Flyers with me, which I may leave somewhere at some point, or I've got them with me anyway.
I will stop talking there and see if I have time for questions you have time for questions.

Maybe an approach to address this topic would be doing graph analysis and subgraph mining, which represents a patterns within a bigger graph, yes, so that's something we're looking at quite a lot now.
The question is what graphs to draw?
Because there are so many interconnections with people, so we're just trying to work out now what connections to ignore and what connections are really meaningful.
But yeah, that's the kind of thing we're looking at with the quantitative side of things.
As briefly as possible, thanks.
That was really interesting talking area, so I'll definitely be following them.
You alluded to the kind of distortions you might get, so for example, that list of top people.
I'd never heard it.
I heard of two of them.
I'm probably out of touch, but um.
I think it's just really comment that the the issues are dealing with the kind of distortions of how people use SoundCloud.
How people follow each other is is quite challenging.
I think it's really interesting area, but I can see how you there's going to be a lot of work in kind of dealing with those distortions compared to the real world.
Coming on that.

That's the absolute crux of this project, which has been so useful working with working with qualitative information as well as the data analysis the two are feeding into each other, and we're finding out where to concentrate our efforts because there's so much data to explore as well.
And so where should we focus things?
Well, let's talk to the musicians themselves and find out.
We don't have anymore time questions, but I'm sure it will be happy to discuss later.
Thank you very much.
